1.title: Introduction to Basic 3D Primitives
1.content: Most simple objects can be broken down into basic 3D primitives or 2D profiles that follow a line.
1.caption2: Rectangular Prisms, indicated by the green bounding box
1.takeawayContent: When combined, these shapes can represent objects like a 9 volt battery

2.title: Less Common Primitives
2.takeawayContent: Note: These primitives may be cut to form halves, quarters, or any subdivision

3.title: Less Common Primitives Combined
3.content: These primitives can then be combined into larger and more complex objects:

4.title: 3D to 2D Correlation
4.content:
Basic primitives can also be broken down into 2D shapes that flow along or revolve about a line.

For example:
4.caption1: A Cube consists of a Square rotated along a line normal to it
4.caption2: A Cone consists of a Triangle rotated about one of its legs
4.caption3: A Sphere consists of a Half Circle rotated about it's straight edge

5.title: Shapes That Vary Along 2 Axes
5.content: Certain 3D shapes vary along two different axes:
5.caption1: A 2D profile rotated about an axis not intersecting itself can be described as a 2D profile following a path.
5.caption2: If this circular path were stretched along the axis normal to it, it would create a helix
5.caption3: Sweeping a 2D circular profile along this path would create a spring.
5.takeawayContent: Objects like these are a natural progression of the basic 3D primitives since they vary in two dimensions rather than one.

6.title: Negative Space
6.content: In addition to positive space, these primitives may also be used to create negative space. When negative space primitives are combined with positive space primitives they create hollow volumes. Examples:
6.caption1:
Pipe
A cylinder with a smaller negative space cylinder inside
6.caption2:
Basketball
A positive space sphere with a smaller negative space sphere inside
6.caption3:
Hole in a piece of wood
A rectangular prism with a negative space cylinder inside
6.caption4:
Bicycle Inner Tube
A torus with a smaller negative space torus inside

7.title: Combining Similar Primitives
7.content:
Often these primitives come in pairs and can be combined to create more complex volumes.

A common volume made using multiple cylinders is a medicine bottle.
7.mediaTitle: For example, a medicine bottle is made using the following progression of cylinders:
7.caption1: A positive cylinder is used to create the bottle's body
7.caption2: A smaller negative cylinder is used to create the cavity within
7.caption3: The process is then repeated on a smaller scale for the bottle's cap

8.title: Combining Different Primitives
8.content: Combining different types of basic primitives can yield more complex shapes that vary in all three dimensions.
8.mediaTitle: For example, a pill shape can be thought of as a cylinder with rounded ends. This consists of:
8.caption1:
A cylinder making the main portion of the body
Two half spheres capping the ends

9.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Introduction
9.content: Let's use some of these basic shapes to create a more complex real-world object: a Smart Switch.
9.caption1:
For simplicity, assume the inside of the smart switch is solid.

We must first need to think about what basic shapes would be used to fill the positive space.

We can then think about what basic shapes would be used to take away the negative space.

These basic primitives are: Rectangular Prisms - Cylinders - Spheres - Wedges - 2D Profiles Swept Along A Path

10.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Rectangular Prisms
10.content: Let's begin by looking at the Rectangular Prisms that make up the volume:
10.caption1: The center of the body is made from one large Positive Space Rectangular Prism (+1, white) with 4 smaller Positive Space Rectangular Prisms flanking each side (+4, Red).
10.caption2: Two smaller Positive Space Rectangular Prisms extend from the back, forming the metal tongs of the plug (+2, Green).
10.caption3: Finally, three Negative Space Rectangular Prisms extend into the body from the front, giving an insertion point for a device to plug in to (-3, Blue).

11.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Cylinders I
11.content: Next let's identify the cylinders that make up the volume:
11.caption1: The 4 corners of the volume are filled in with 4 Positive Space quarter cylinders (+4, Yellow).
11.caption2: One Negative Space cylinder extends into the body, giving room for the button (-1, Checkered).
11.caption3: One Positive Space cylinder fills the hole made previously, making the button (+1, Light Green).

12.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Cylinders II
12.caption1: Two Positive Space half cylinders form the tips of the rear prongs (+2, Blue).
12.caption2: One Positive Space cylinder extends from the rear, forming the ground prong (+1, Purple)
12.caption3: One more Negative Space cylinder extends into the body, forming the rest of the insertion point for a device to plug in to (-1, Checkered)

13.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Spheres
13.content: Next let's identify the spheres that make up the volume:
13.caption1: A small portion of a large Negative Space sphere scallops the button (-1, Light Blue).
13.caption2: This shows the Negative Space sphere as pink.
13.caption3: A Positive Space half cylinder caps off the ground prong on the rear (+1, Orange).

14.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - Wedges
14.content: Next let's identify the wedges that make up the volume:
14.caption1: Two Negative Space wedges cut into each of the rear tongs to assist with guiding the tongs during insertion (-2x2=-4, Hot Pink).

15.title: Case Study: Smart Switch - 2D Profile Swept Along A Path
15.content: Finally, let's identify the 2D Profile Swept Along a Path, the final feature that makes up this volume:
15.caption1: A small square is swept along a path just offset from the front surface outer edge, creating a Negative Space (-1, Black).
15.caption2:
Totalling these up, there are a net:

  • +4 Rectangular Prisms (1+4+2-3)
  • +6 Cylinders (4-1+1+2+1-1)
  • 0 spheres (1-1)
  • -4 wedges
  • -1 2D Profiles Swept Along A Path

16.title: Conclusion & Quiz Readiness
16.content: With these concepts in mind, look around the room and try to break down everyday objects into basic primitives - whether that be 2D shapes along a path or 3D primitives.
16.takeawayContent:
Most mechanical objects and simple items can be broken down into discrete shapes.

Once these shapes have been identified, modeling them and representing them digitally becomes a much easier next step.
